questions.question: Which numeric variable shows the most variation and can it be explained by a few other measurements? Return as JSON with keys: target, predictors, r_squared, adj_r_squared, n_significant, coefficients, p_values.
questions.hint: Pick the numeric column with the highest variance as the target, identify its three strongest correlated numeric features, fit an OLS regression, and report the R², adjusted R², significant predictor count, coefficients and p-values.
questions.output_schema: A JSON object with exactly 6 keys: "target" (column name), "predictors" (list of 3 column names), "r_squared" (rounded to 4 decimals), "adj_r_squared" (rounded to 4 decimals), "n_significant" (integer count of predictors with p < 0.05), "coefficients" (dict mapping predictor names to coefficients rounded to 4 decimals), and "p_values" (dict mapping predictor names to p-values rounded to 6 decimals). Example: {"target": "price", "predictors": ["sqft", "bedrooms", "age"], "r_squared": 0.7234, "adj_r_squared": 0.7156, "n_significant": 2, "coefficients": {"sqft": 123.45, "bedrooms": 5000.12, "age": -200.34}, "p_values": {"sqft": 0.000001, "bedrooms": 0.023456, "age": 0.156789}}

questions.question: Which numeric measurement in the wine dataset exhibits the highest absolute skewness, and what are its mean and 95% bootstrap confidence interval? Return as JSON with keys: column, skewness, mean, ci_lower, ci_upper, std_error, n_bootstrap.
questions.hint: Calculate skewness for all numeric columns, select the most skewed one, then perform bootstrap resampling of its values to estimate the mean, confidence interval, and standard error.
questions.output_schema: A JSON object with exactly 7 keys: "column" (name of most skewed column), "skewness" (rounded to 4 decimals), "mean" (rounded to 4 decimals), "ci_lower" (lower bound of 95% CI, rounded to 4 decimals), "ci_upper" (upper bound, rounded to 4 decimals), "std_error" (bootstrap standard error, rounded to 4 decimals), and "n_bootstrap" (integer, the number of bootstrap samples). Example: {"column": "income", "skewness": 2.3456, "mean": 50000.1234, "ci_lower": 48500.5678, "ci_upper": 51500.9012, "std_error": 750.3456, "n_bootstrap": 1000}

questions.question: Which numeric variable shows the strongest relationship with the most variable measurement, and how well can it predict it? Return as JSON with keys: target, best_predictor, correlation, r_squared, coefficient, p_value.
questions.hint: Identify the numeric column with highest variance, compute absolute correlations with it, select the top correlated feature, fit a simple OLS regression, and report the stats.
questions.output_schema: A JSON object with exactly 6 keys: "target" (column name), "best_predictor" (column name), "correlation" (rounded to 3 decimals), "r_squared" (rounded to 4 decimals), "coefficient" (rounded to 4 decimals), and "p_value" (rounded to 6 decimals). Example: {"target": "price", "best_predictor": "sqft", "correlation": 0.834, "r_squared": 0.6956, "coefficient": 135.2847, "p_value": 0.000001}

questions.question: Does the most variable numeric measurement differ between two groups formed by splitting another feature at its median? Return as JSON with keys: target_column, grouping_column, group1, group2, mean1, mean2, t_statistic, p_value, significant.
questions.hint: Find the numeric column with the highest variance, create a binary group from a different numeric column using its median, then compare group means with a t‑test.
questions.output_schema: A JSON object with exactly 9 keys: "target_column", "grouping_column", "group1", "group2", "mean1" (rounded to 4 decimals), "mean2" (rounded to 4 decimals), "t_statistic" (rounded to 4 decimals), "p_value" (rounded to 6 decimals), and "significant" (boolean, true if p < 0.05). Example: {"target_column": "score", "grouping_column": "gender", "group1": "M", "group2": "F", "mean1": 75.4321, "mean2": 78.1234, "t_statistic": -2.3456, "p_value": 0.019234, "significant": true}

questions.question: Which numeric column in the wine dataset appears most normally distributed? Return as JSON with keys: column, ks_statistic, p_value, is_normal, sample_mean, sample_std.
questions.hint: Identify the column with the smallest absolute skewness, standardize its values, then run a Kolmogorov‑Smirnov test against a standard normal distribution.
questions.output_schema: A JSON object with exactly 6 keys: "column" (tested column), "ks_statistic" (rounded to 4 decimals), "p_value" (rounded to 6 decimals), "is_normal" (boolean, true if p >= 0.05), "sample_mean" (rounded to 4 decimals), and "sample_std" (rounded to 4 decimals). Example: {"column": "height", "ks_statistic": 0.0456, "p_value": 0.234567, "is_normal": true, "sample_mean": 170.1234, "sample_std": 10.5678}

questions.question: Which pair of numeric variables exhibits the strongest monotonic correlation? Return as JSON with keys: columns, spearman_rho, p_value, interpretation.
questions.hint: Calculate the Spearman correlation matrix for all numeric columns, set the diagonal to zero, and identify the pair with the highest absolute correlation.
questions.output_schema: A JSON object with exactly 4 keys: "columns" (list of 2 column names, alphabetically sorted), "spearman_rho" (correlation coefficient rounded to 4 decimals), "p_value" (rounded to 6 decimals), and "interpretation" (string: "strong", "moderate", "weak", or "negligible"). Example: {"columns": ["age", "income"], "spearman_rho": 0.7234, "p_value": 0.000001, "interpretation": "strong"}

questions.question: Which numeric column in the wine dataset has the highest variance, and what are its Q1, Q3, IQR, lower and upper fences, and outlier count? Return as JSON with keys: column, q1, q3, iqr, lower_fence, upper_fence, n_outliers.
questions.hint: Identify the column with the largest variance, then compute its quartiles, IQR, fences, and count points outside the fences.
questions.output_schema: A JSON object with exactly 7 keys: "column" (analyzed column), "q1" (25th percentile rounded to 4 decimals), "q3" (75th percentile rounded to 4 decimals), "iqr" (rounded to 4 decimals), "lower_fence" (rounded to 4 decimals), "upper_fence" (rounded to 4 decimals), and "n_outliers" (integer count). Example: {"column": "salary", "q1": 45000.0000, "q3": 75000.0000, "iqr": 30000.0000, "lower_fence": 0.0000, "upper_fence": 120000.0000, "n_outliers": 23}

questions.question: Which numeric column exhibits the highest variance, and does its distribution follow a normal pattern? Return as JSON with keys: distribution, median, iqr (or mean, std if normal).
questions.hint: Find the numeric feature with the largest variance, assess its normality (e.g., Shapiro‑Wilk), then report mean/std for normal or median/IQR for non‑normal.
questions.output_schema: A JSON object with exactly 3 keys. If normal: {"distribution": "normal", "mean": <number>, "std": <number>}. If non-normal: {"distribution": "non-normal", "median": <number>, "iqr": <number>}. The "iqr" value is Q3 minus Q1 as a single number. All numeric values rounded to 3 decimal places.

questions.question: Which two numeric features have the strongest correlation, and how does that correlation shift after discarding extreme outliers? Return as JSON with keys: columns, original_correlation, outliers_removed, clean_correlation.
questions.hint: Find the pair with highest absolute Pearson correlation, drop rows where either value is beyond 3 standard deviations, then recompute the correlation on the cleaned data.
questions.output_schema: A JSON object with exactly 4 keys: "columns" (list of 2 column names, alphabetically sorted), "original_correlation" (rounded to 3 decimals), "outliers_removed" (integer count), and "clean_correlation" (rounded to 3 decimals). Example: {"columns": ["col_a", "col_b"], "original_correlation": 0.847, "outliers_removed": 12, "clean_correlation": 0.891}

questions.question: I wonder how many numeric measurements contain extreme values and the total number of such outliers. Return as JSON with keys: columns_with_outliers, total_outliers.
questions.hint: Apply a 3‑sigma rule to each numeric column to identify outliers and aggregate the counts.
questions.output_schema: A JSON object with exactly 2 keys: "columns_with_outliers" (integer count of columns containing at least one outlier) and "total_outliers" (integer total count of outlier values across all columns). Example: {"columns_with_outliers": 3, "total_outliers": 47}

questions.question: How many numeric features have outliers and what is the total number of outlier values in the data? Return as JSON with keys: columns_with_outliers, total_outliers.
questions.hint: Use a 2.5‑standard‑deviation threshold on each numeric column to flag outliers, then count columns with any outliers and sum all outlier instances.
questions.output_schema: A JSON object with exactly 2 keys: "columns_with_outliers" (integer count of columns containing at least one outlier) and "total_outliers" (integer total count of outlier values across all columns). Example: {"columns_with_outliers": 3, "total_outliers": 47}

questions.question: Which numeric feature in the wine dataset exhibits the highest relative variability? Return as JSON with keys: column, cv, mean, std.
questions.hint: Calculate the coefficient of variation (std/mean*100) for each numeric column and identify the one with the largest value.
questions.output_schema: A JSON object with exactly 4 keys: "column" (name of column with highest CV), "cv" (coefficient of variation as percentage rounded to 2 decimals), "mean" (rounded to 4 decimals), and "std" (rounded to 4 decimals). Example: {"column": "price", "cv": 45.23, "mean": 1234.5678, "std": 558.4567}

questions.question: Which two numeric measurements in the wine dataset show the strongest correlation? Return as JSON with keys: columns, correlation.
questions.hint: Compute the absolute correlation matrix for all numeric columns and identify the pair with the highest off‑diagonal correlation.
questions.output_schema: A JSON object with exactly two keys: "columns" (a list of the two column names, alphabetically sorted) and "correlation" (the correlation coefficient rounded to 3 decimal places). Example: {"columns": ["col_a", "col_b"], "correlation": 0.847}

questions.question: Which two numeric attributes in the wine dataset have the weakest linear relationship? Return as JSON with keys: columns, correlation.
questions.hint: Compute the absolute correlation matrix for numeric columns, ignore the diagonal, and find the pair with the smallest correlation.
questions.output_schema: A JSON object with exactly two keys: "columns" (a list of the two column names, alphabetically sorted) and "correlation" (the absolute correlation value rounded to 3 decimal places). Example: {"columns": ["col_a", "col_b"], "correlation": 0.012}

questions.question: Which numeric attribute in the wine dataset has the highest variance, and what is its mean value? Return as JSON with keys: mean.
questions.hint: Identify the numeric column with the largest variance, then calculate its average.
questions.output_schema: A single number (the mean), rounded to 3 decimal places

questions.question: Which numeric measurement has the lowest average value, and what is its variability? Return as JSON with keys: result.
questions.hint: Identify the column with the smallest mean, then compute its standard deviation.
questions.output_schema: A single number (the standard deviation), rounded to 3 decimal places

questions.question: I’m curious whether any features in this wine dataset have a high proportion of missing values. Return as JSON with keys: count, columns.
questions.hint: Calculate the percentage of missing entries for each column and identify those exceeding a 5% threshold.
questions.output_schema: A JSON object with exactly 2 keys: "count" (integer) and "columns" (list of column names, alphabetically sorted). Example: {"count": 3, "columns": ["col_a", "col_b", "col_c"]}

questions.question: Are there any features in this wine dataset that have a substantial amount of missing data? Return as JSON with keys: count, columns.
questions.hint: Calculate the percentage of missing values for each column and list those above a 10% threshold.
questions.output_schema: A JSON object with exactly 2 keys: "count" (integer) and "columns" (list of column names, alphabetically sorted). Example: {"count": 3, "columns": ["col_a", "col_b", "col_c"]}

questions.question: Which numeric feature in the wine dataset has the largest range, and what are its 10th, 25th, 50th, 75th, and 90th percentiles? Return as JSON with keys: column, p10, p25, p50, p75, p90.
questions.hint: Identify the column with the biggest (max - min) spread, then compute the specified percentiles.
questions.output_schema: A JSON object with exactly 6 keys: "column" (analyzed column), "p10" (10th percentile rounded to 4 decimals), "p25" (25th percentile), "p50" (median), "p75" (75th percentile), and "p90" (90th percentile). Example: {"column": "income", "p10": 25000.0000, "p25": 40000.0000, "p50": 55000.0000, "p75": 75000.0000, "p90": 100000.0000}

questions.question: Which numeric column in this wine dataset shows the greatest variability, and what are its basic descriptive statistics? Return as JSON with keys: column, count, mean, std, min, max, median, skewness, kurtosis.
questions.hint: Find the numeric feature with the highest variance, then calculate its count, mean, std, min, max, median, skewness, and kurtosis.
questions.output_schema: A JSON object with exactly 9 keys: "column", "count" (integer), "mean" (rounded to 4 decimals), "std", "min", "max", "median", "skewness", and "kurtosis" (all rounded to 4 decimals). Example: {"column": "age", "count": 1000, "mean": 35.4567, "std": 12.3456, "min": 18.0000, "max": 85.0000, "median": 34.0000, "skewness": 0.5678, "kurtosis": -0.2345}
